title: Franz Lachner
text:
Franz Paul Lachner (2 April 1803 – 20 January 1890) was a <a href="Germans">German</a> composer and <a href="conducting">conductor</a>.
Biography.
Lachner was born in <a href="Rain%20am%20Lech">Rain am Lech</a> to a musical family (his brothers <a href="Ignaz%20Lachner">Ignaz</a>, Theodor and <a href="Vinzenz%20Lachner">Vinzenz</a> also became musicians). He studied music with <a href="Simon%20Sechter">Simon Sechter</a> and <a href="Maximilian%20Stadler">Maximilian, the Abbé Stadler</a>. He conducted at the <a href="Theater%20am%20K%C3%A4rntnertor">Theater am Kärntnertor</a> in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>. In 1834, he became "<a href="Kapellmeister">Kapellmeister</a>" at <a href="Mannheim">Mannheim</a>. As a result of composers' aesthetic comparisons of Beethoven's symphonic output with efforts afterwards, in 1835, there was a competition in Vienna for the best new symphony sponsored by Tobias Haslinger of the music publishing firm with no fewer than 57 entries. Lachner received first prize with his 5th Symphony "Sinfonia passionata, or Preis-Symphonie" and became royal "Kapellmeister" at <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, becoming a major figure in its musical life, conducting at the opera and various concerts and festivals. His career there came to a sudden end in 1864 after <a href="Richard%20Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>'s disciple <a href="Hans%20von%20B%C3%BClow">Hans von Bülow</a> took over Lachner's duties. Lachner remained officially in his post on extended leave for a few years until his contract expired.
Work.
Lachner was a well-known and prolific composer in his day, though he is not now considered a major composer. His work, influenced by <a href="Ludwig%20van%20Beethoven">Ludwig van Beethoven</a> and his friend <a href="Franz%20Schubert">Franz Schubert</a>, is regarded as competent and craftsman-like, but is now generally little known. Among his greatest successes were his opera "Catharina Cornaro" (1841, preceding <a href="Gaetano%20Donizetti">Donizetti</a>'s <a href="Caterina%20Cornaro%20%28opera%29">opera</a> by three years), his "<a href="Music%20for%20the%20Requiem%20Mass">Requiem</a>", and his seventh orchestral <a href="suite%20%28music%29">suite</a> (1881).
In the present day it may be his <a href="organ%20%28music%29">organ</a> <a href="sonata">sonata</a>s (Opp. 175, 176, 177) and <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a>, in particular his music for <a href="wind%20instrument">wind instrument</a>s, that receive the most attention, though his string quartets and some of his eight symphonies have been performed and recorded. His songs, some of which are set to the same texts that Schubert used, contributed to the development of the German <a href="Lied">Lied</a>.
For performances of <a href="Luigi%20Cherubini">Cherubini</a>'s "<a href="M%C3%A9d%C3%A9e%20%28Cherubini%29">Médée</a>" in Frankfurt in 1855, Lachner composed <a href="recitative">recitative</a>s to replace the original spoken dialogue, and it was this version, translated into Italian, which was used in many twentieth-century revivals and recordings of that opera.
